article.headline: Sooners win without a point in final 8:43
article.story: OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- In only its second game of the season outside its own gym, No. 7 Oklahoma needed some help from an emerging star to beat Princeton 58-55 Saturday in the All-College Classic. Having played seven of its last eight games on the road, Princeton quieted the Ford Center crowd of about 10,000 with 60-percent shooting effort in the first half, largely on layups inside. But Oklahoma sophomore DeAngelo Alexander had a season-high 22 points -- 12 coming in the second half -- and was selected as the tourney's Most Valuable Player. It was the third time this season he has led the Sooners in scoring. DeAngelo is getting a lot more confident, Oklahoma coach Kelvin Sampson said. "I can tell because he's finishing plays," Sampson said. "DeAngelo is a really good basketball player. I thought his defense in the second half was outstanding. The win was No. 400 for Sampson, who is 224-81 in his 10th season at Oklahoma. Sampson has guided the Sooners to the NCAA tournament each of the past nine seasons. Sampson said the Sooners are still a work in progress. "It will be a while. We're so new," said Sampson, who starts a pair of sophomores and a freshman. Princeton and Oklahoma swapped the lead six times in the first half with Princeton scoring often on backdoor cuts. The lead changed hands three times over the final four minutes of the half with Princeton taking a 27-26 edge into the break after Will Venable knifed through the Oklahoma defense for a layup with 21 seconds remaining. Oklahoma (10-0) took the lead for good on its first possession of the second half, when Kevin Bookout muscled inside and laid the ball in for two of his six points. Oklahoma led by as many as 10 points twice in the second half, but Princeton (5-5) rallied to cut the deficit to three with 2:50 remaining. Oklahoma ended a six-minute scoring drought when Jason Detrick hit a pair of free throws with 33.9 seconds remaining. The Tigers missed their final two shots, including Ed Persia's 21-foot jumper from the top of the key as time expired. Persia led the Tigers with 19 points. Scott Greenman was next for Princeton with 14 points. Oklahoma point guard Drew Lavender was the only other Sooner in double figures, finishing with 11 points and three assists. Oklahoma's Jabahri Brown blocked three shots just five days after exiting a game against Texas-Pan American after being kicked in the jaw. Wearing a mouthpiece for the first time this season, Brown scored six points in 30 minutes and was 3-of-4 from the field. Prince coach John Thompson was not happy with a moral victory. "We played well for stretches but there were other times," he said. Thompson was asked if he was surprised Alexander, who has battled a shoulder injury all season, played so well in the second half. "He's a very good player," Thompson said. "He appeared a little too healthy."
